Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Situation2: They organize immediate support and counseling for community members facing a crisis, such as a natural disaster or sudden loss.
Story: My phone buzzed with a flurry of notifications as I sat at my desk, lines of code blurring before my eyes. The QA team had flagged a critical bug—users were getting kicked out of the system at random, and the reports were piling up. My manager’s message was clear: “We need a fix ASAP. Users are frustrated.” I started scanning logs, my mind racing through possible causes, when another notification popped up—this time from the church group chat. There’d been a fire in one of our community members’ homes. People were scared, some displaced, and they needed immediate support. “Pastor, can you come? We need you,” someone wrote. I stared at the two screens, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. My team expected me to be the problem-solver, the one who kept things running. My congregation needed me to be present, to offer comfort and hope. My heart pounded as I tried to decide where I was needed most, torn between the urgent demands of my job and the desperate needs of my community.
